title: Chicken Nanban
description: Crispy fried chicken cutlets are marinated briefly, coated, and deep-fried then drenched in a tangy-sweet nanban vinegar sauce and topped with a creamy tartar sauce. Bright, slightly sweet and acidic flavors balance the rich fried texture for a comforting Japanese-style dish.

steps.text: Prepare the chicken: trim and optionally butterfly thighs, then pound to even thickness about 1/2 inch; season both sides with salt and pepper.
Make the nanban sauce: combine rice vinegar, soy sauce, sugar, mirin (if using) and dashi; stir until sugar dissolves and keep warm or at room temperature.
Set up dredging station: one bowl with flour and cornstarch mixture, one with beaten eggs, and one with panko breadcrumbs; press chicken into flour, then egg, then panko to fully coat.

Heat oil in a deep skillet to 170-175°C (340-350°F) for frying; test with a breadcrumb to ensure steady bubbling; fry chicken in batches until golden and cooked through (internal temp 74°C/165°F), about 4–5 minutes per side for shallow frying or 6–7 minutes total for smaller pieces.
Drain fried chicken on a wire rack for 1–2 minutes, then briefly dip or pour the nanban sauce over the cutlets so they are coated but not soggy; let rest 2 minutes to absorb flavor.

Make tartar sauce while chicken rests: mix mayonnaise with finely diced onion, grated carrot, chopped pickles, capers if using, lemon juice, chopped parsley, and a pinch of salt and pepper; chill briefly if desired.
Slice chicken into portions, plate over rice or shredded cabbage, spoon tartar sauce over each portion and garnish with parsley and lemon wedge; serve immediately.
